content: Is IMAP/POP access enabled on your Microsoft account? You can find the instructions from Microsoft Support here under "Enable POP or IMAP access in Outlook.com". This Thunderbird support article may also have some troubleshooting steps that you could try.

content: Please clarify what you want to do. Installing thunderbird is not dependent on having an import.
creator: davidsk

content: You will have to use GPG directly outside of Thunderbird in order to add additional identities to your key. Assuming GPG is already installed on your device with your secret key imported, you can use the gpg --edit-key $YOUR_KEY_ID adduid command to add another identity to your key and then import it back into Thunderbird.
creator: bbonacci

content: Further testing revealed that the error only occurs in user profiles, not in the administrator profile. This is interesting because no security settings were changed.
creator: hagen.haentzschel

content:
Per poter inquadrare il problema prova a fornire queste informazioni:

  1. Versione di Thunderbird
  2. Versione del sistema operativo
  3. Provider delle caselle email (Gmail, Libero, Hotmail, etc.)
  4. Tipologia di account (POP3, IMAP)
  5. Estensioni installate
  6. Messaggi di errore che vengono visualizzati durante l'utilizzo di Thunderbird
  7. Software di sicurezza eventualmente presenti (Antivirus e simili)
  8. Screenshot del problema (se utile a chiarire il contesto)
creator: @next

content:
Il problema si verifica su tutte le cassette configurate all'interno di Thunderbird

Di seguito i dati richiesti:

  1. Thunderbird Desktop Version 140.2.0esr | Released August 19, 2025 32 bit
  2. SO:Microsoft Windows 11 Pro Versione: 10.0.26100 build 26100
  3. Caselle Gmail e Libero
  4. Entrambe tipologie sia POP3 che IMAP
  5. Estensione prente: Textmarker - Highlights selected text when composing e-mails.
  6. Nessun messaggio di errore Compare a video
  7. Antivirus presente McAfee LifeSafe

Allego lo screenshot che compare dopo che ho esteso il settaggio a tutte le Cartelle presenti. Al successivo riavvio dei thunderbird questi settaggi vengono persi.

Spero di aver dato tutte le Informazioni necessarie.

content:
Hi Jerry,

You can restore your profile from the last back-up copy of your important files that you made.

If your messages are still available to be downloaded, then they are on the mail server and you can access them 1) through webmail and 2) by setting up your accounts in Thunderbird again.

content:
M Loudis said
Here it is. All of my subfolders are gone.

This is not the screen shot I had asked for since it shows the Local Folders in the folder pane. I want to have a look at the Local Folders in the folder Mail in the profile to verify whether your "Exemple.sbd" folders are accompanied by a mailbox file "Exemple" without extension. If you have created a folder "Exemple" in Local Folders (in the folder pane) und then created sub-folders in "Exemple" the presence of the file Exemple is essentiel for displaying Exemple and its sub-folders in the folder pane, even if itself contains no messages. I have seen several users "loosing" their folders and messages in Local Folders after applying so-called "Cleaning tools" which clean up every mailbox file with a 0 (zero) kB size they can find in profile...

I add a picture with the path to my Local Folders in Thunderbird profile (on a Mac). I would like to see the contents of these Local folders
creator: Mapenzi

content: I don't have that view available. When I look under C:>Program Files> there is no Thunderbird file, even though I kept Thunderbird open. I then decided to reinstall Thunderbird, and it's also running. The newly installed is V146, while the original Thunderbird is 128. So, I guess it never updated itself, which may explain why I started with problems about a week ago when my filters stopped working. And within the past couple of days it started sending "Authentication Failure" messages. This was before I tried to backup [edited email from public] @gmail.com. I'll include all the screenshots. I have a feeling that something is corrupted and I'll have to start from scratch.

content: I can't reproduce your view. In fact, Thunderbird was missing from C:>Program Files. So, I downloaded it again and found that the version was later than the Thunderbird I still had open. The original is V128; the one from today is V146. Apparently V128 wasn't updating even though it was set for auto updates. When I checked C:\Users\***\AppData\Roaming\Mozilla\Thunderbird all I had was a Crash Reports file. When I checked C:\Users\***\AppData\Roaming\Thunderbird\Profiles I have two, both with todays date. One has 48 items, the other only 1. I will include screenshots of all of this. Several days ago I started to experience problems with my filters not working. And since yesterday I'm getting a pop-up with "authentication failure". This has all occurred with V128. This was before I tried a backup/restore of one email account today. I suspect that V128 is corrupted in some way. If so, I have the feeling that I'm going to start over with V146. I'd like not to as I'll be loosing all of my local folders and mail. Maybe there's something else I'm not doing? Thanks.

content: More information is needed, as Local Folders are normally created subordinate to the Mail folder. You can click help>troubleshootinginformation, then scroll down to 'profile folder', then click 'open folder. You will now be in the profile and the Mail directory should appear in the list of profile components. Click it and see if Local folders are there. If now, posting screenshots of what you see may help
creator: davidsk

content: The 64bit has been available for years, so I am guessing you may have been upgrading a 32bit version. I will assume you installed from thunderbird.net. If you installed from Microsoft let me know before doing anything. - for safety, make sure thunderbird s not running - enter %appdataS% in search box on windows tasks bar - that should open to the appdata\roaming directory - highlight the thunderbird folder and copy it to somewhere else for safety - now uninstall thunderbird - if it prompts to delete data, tell it NO - now install thunderbird from https://www.thunderbird.net/en-US/thunderbird/all/ Pick whether you want ESR or Monthly - start thunderbird. if it doesn't open to your accounts, just close and exit - do NOT try to fix - now take the backed up thunderbird folder - repeat the %appata% to task bar and when window opens to appdata\roaming, paste your thunderbird over the top of the existing thunderbird folder. you will be prompted for the overwrite. allow it - now start thunderbird and your accounts should be there
creator: davidsk

content:
Hello and many thanks for such a fast response.

I'm guessing the 'S' in appdata was just a typo? Thanks again Alan

content: Yes, a typo. :) if you had installed from MS, the locations of everything is different.
